doc.title: J.P.Morgan
doc.source_uri: 25.9月 普通个人版/9.1 普通个人版/JPM/Oil Markets Weekly Tariffs on India kick inRussian oil flows likely to continue at limited discountsOil Markets Weekly T_2025-08-28

passages.text: Tariffs on India kick in—Russian oil flows likely to continue at limited discounts

Despite higher tariffs, India continues to buy Russian crude at reduced levels, a trend likely to persist until a trade deal is finalized and Russia maintains discounts Russia has successfully redirected the 0.5 mbd drop in Indian exports but is unlikely to offer discounts beyond the current \(\) 2.60/bbll\$ preferring to cut production over providing the deep discounts seen in 2022 Since 2021, India's crude imports and refinery runs have grown significantly, while exports have remained flat due to rising domestic demand However, of the 1.8 mbd of Russian crude imported by India, nearly 1 mbs is refined and exported, mainly by private operators With only 0.2 mbd of this being shipped to the EU, India should face no issues in complying with EU third- country intermediaries restrictions India operates within global policy frameworks, with Russia bearing the responsibility for delivery

The US has doubled tariffs on imports from India to \(50\%\) over its purchases of Russian oil, raising duties on the world's fifth largest economy to some of the highest in the world. The levy came into effect at 12:01 AM US eastern time on Wednesday. Several of India's exports to the US, including electronics, pharmaceuticals, petroleum fuels and critical minerals, are currently exempt from these tariffs. These await Section 232 investigations, which will determine if tariffs will be subsequently imposed (Five questions on US tariffs on India, Jain et al., 26 August 2025).
1. Despite the threat of higher tariffs, India has continued to buy Russian crude, albeit at lower levels—a trend that is likely to continue until a trade deal is finalized.

Russian crude shipments to India averaged about 1.6 mbd in July and August, down from 2.1 mbd in June and 1.8 mbd during the first half of the year, although the import volumes for July and August will only be reflected in shipment data from September (Figure 1). Indian officials have responded with resolve, indicating no immediate plans to cease Russian oil imports. The government has not mandated refiners to reduce Russian crude purchases, allowing companies to make operational decisions independently. Additionally, government officials have emphasized that national interests take precedence over commercial considerations, stressing that access to discounted Russian crude remains critical for India's energy security and macroeconomic stability.
Figure 1: India imports of Russian crude by type of refiner Kbd
Figure 2: Russia exports of crude by country Kbd

While India is unlikely to fully halt Russian imports, some refineries may scale back their purchases, aiming to balance geopolitical risks while preserving price advantages. Alternative supplies can be secured from the Middle East, the US, Latin America, and West Africa, and some substitution has already begun, as evidenced by the widening Murban- Brent futures spread, which has reached its widest point since June 2022 at \(\) 1.80/bbll. Still, Indian government officials maintain that Russia will remain a central part of India's energy security in the near term, especially if Russia continues to offer discounted prices.

However, Russia is unlikely to offer India discounts below the current \(\) 2.60\$ per barrel, let alone the steep discounts provided in 2022, when the country was urgently trying to place its oil into the global market. Back in 2022, Russia was concerned that the post- COVID surplus in production capacity was large enough to potentially replace some of its own capacity if it had to cut production due to Western sanctions. Additionally, there were worries that potential buyers might pressure Russian revenues by demanding massive discounts. Today, such concerns no longer exist. The world does not have enough oil to fully replace Russian exports. Even if countries alarmed by Trump's tariff threats hypothetically wanted to explore alternatives, they simply wouldn't be able to find them. The initial discounts ballooned to almost \(\) 14\$ versus Brent, but higher costs of shipping following sanctions reduced the discounts. Under these conditions, if Russia finds itself unable to sell its oil, it would be economically more beneficial for the country to cut production and drive prices higher rather than offer a deep discount.

However, in the three and a half years since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Western leaders have demonstrated little willingness to endure the higher prices that effective oil export sanctions would entail. We anticipate this status quo will continue.

So far, Russia has effectively managed to redirect the 0.5 mbd drop in Indian exports (Figure 2). Our previous research estimated that, over time, Russia would be able to reroute a total of 1.2 mbd of its seaborne exports (Who would buy Russian oil? 31 July 2025):

- 0.8 mbd to countries like Egypt, Malaysia, Vietnam, and Brunei- China's blending capacity could absorb an additional 1 mbd of Russian crude. This, however, would raise Russia's share to 25% of China's imports, surpassing the 20% threshold—a level no single country has exceeded over the past 20 years. If China were to boost Russia's share to around 20% of its oil import basket, it would allow for an additional 400 kbd of Russian crude purchases.

Russia, on its side, would also likely counteract with a closure of the 1.5- 1.6 mbd Caspian Pipeline Consortium (CPC)—a crucial artery for Kazakh crude, most of which flows through the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossiysk (Zugzwang, 7 August 2025).
Figure 3: Kazakhstan's CPC crude export nonvorossiysk kbd
Source: Kpler, J.P. Morgan Commodities Research

India—one of the largest buyers of crude oil in the world—imports approximately 5 mbd of crude, with substantial quantities sourced from the Middle East and Russia and a smaller flow from West Africa, Latin America, and the US. Over \(20\%\) of these imports are then refined, largely by private firms, for the international market, with about half of the exported volumes directed to Asia, and the remainder going to Africa, Europe, and the Americas (Figures 4 & 5).

Majority of the refined crude, however, stays at home. By number, since 2021, India's imports of crude have increased by nearly 0.8 mbd, and refinery production has risen by a similar margin. Meanwhile, exports of refined petroleum products have remained relatively stable, up only 60 kbd, as rising domestic demand has absorbed the increased production (Figure 6). State refiners service about \(80\%\) of the domestic market, while private refiners like Reliance Industries, which operates the world's largest refining complex in Jamnagar on India's west coast, primarily cater to the export market.
Figure 4: India's crude oil intake split by domestic vs export markets Mbd
Figure 6: India's crude oil imports, exports and refinery runs Mbd

Of the 1.8 mbd of Russian crude imported by India, almost 1 mbd is refined and exported, predominantly by private operators, according to our estimates (Figures 7 & 8). The remaining 0.8 mbd is retained domestically, where the Indian government leverages access to discounted Russian crude to mitigate the fiscal burden of fuel subsidies and maintain the profitability of refiners. Shortly after the onset of the war in Ukraine, the price of crude basket in India stood at \(114 / bbl\). Since then, it has decreased by 40% to \(69 in August. However, during the same period, the retail price of gasoline in India has only dropped by 14%.

In July, the EU announced new restrictions on Russian oil purchases, set to take effect in January 2026, which will target third- country intermediaries. This move represents a comprehensive ban on imports of refined oil products made from Russian crude that are processed abroad and delivered to the EU. Considering that India exports only around 200 kbd of petroleum products to the EU and UK, we anticipate that the country's refiners will find it relatively straightforward to comply with these regulations.
